Over-the-Air Federated Multi-Task Learning via Model Sparsification and Turbo Compressed Sensing

Haoming Ma, Xiaojun Yuan,  Zhi Ding,  Dian Fan, Jun Fang H. Ma, X. Yuan, D. Fan and J. Fang are with the National Key Laboratory of Science and Technology on Communication, the University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu, China (e-mail:hmma@std.uestc.edu.cn; xjyuan@uestc.edu.cn; df@std.uestc.edu.cn; junfang@uestc.edu.cn). Z. Ding is with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of California at Davis, Davis, CA 95616 USA (e-mail:zding@ucdavis.edu). The corresponding author is Xiaojun Yuan.
Abstract

To achieve communication-efficient federated multi-task learning (FMTL), we propose an over-the-air FMTL (OA-FMTL) framework, where multiple learning tasks deployed on edge devices share a non-orthogonal fading channel under the coordination of an edge server (ES). In OA-FMTL, the local updates of edge devices are sparsified, compressed, and then sent over the uplink channel in a superimposed fashion. The ES employs over-the-air computation in the presence of inter-task interference. More specifically, the model aggregations of all the tasks are reconstructed from the channel observations concurrently, based on a modified version of the turbo compressed sensing (Turbo-CS) algorithm (named as M-Turbo-CS). We analyze the performance of the proposed OA-FMTL framework together with the M-Turbo-CS algorithm. Furthermore, based on the analysis, we formulate a communication-learning optimization problem to improve the system performance by adjusting the power allocation among the tasks at the edge devices. Numerical simulations show that our proposed OA-FMTL effectively suppresses the inter-task interference, and achieves a learning performance comparable to its counterpart with orthogonal multi-task transmission. It is also shown that the proposed inter-task power allocation optimization algorithm substantially reduces the overall communication overhead by appropriately adjusting the power allocation among the tasks.

Index Terms:
Federated multi-task learning, over-the-air computation, turbo compressed sensing.

I Introduction

With the availability of a massive amount of data at mobile edge devices, there is a growing interest in providing artificial intelligence (AI) services, such as computer vision [1] and natural language processing [2], at the edge of wireless networks. To utilize these data, conventional machine learning (ML) requires edge devices to upload their local data to a central node for model training. However, uploading such a huge volume of data by wireless communication incurs a huge cost of communication resources and compromises data privacy. To address these issues, federated learning (FL) has emerged as a popular framework for model training in a distributive and confidential manner [3]. In the FL framework, each edge device trains its local model based on its local data; and then transmits its local model parameters or gradients to an edge server (ES). The ES updates its global model parameters via model aggregation; and then broadcasts the updated global model to the edge devices. Compared with centralized learning, FL significantly relieves the communication burden and reduces the risk of data breaches.

In federated edge learning, a huge amount of model parameters need to be uploaded from massive distributed edge devices to the ES (referred to as uplink), where limited uplink channel resources (e.g., bandwidth, time, and space) become a critical bottleneck of efficient communication. To achieve communication-efficient FL, extensive research effort has been devoted to the uplink communication design [4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11]. The authors in [5, 6] pointed out that the local model parameters or gradients can be sparsified, compressed, and quantized before transmission to reduce the uplink communication cost without causing substantial losses in model accuracy. The authors in [7, 8] proposed further improvements to reduce the number of communication rounds required for convergence. Different from digital model uploading in [5, 6, 7, 8], another popular uplink transmission strategy called over-the-air computation has emerged to support analog model uploading from massive edge devices [9]. Instead of orthogonal resource allocation among the devices to avoid interference, over-the-air computation allows the devices to share radio resources in model uploading by leveraging the signal-superposition property of analog transmission to conduct model aggregation over the air. To name a few, the authors in [10, 11] proposed gradient sparsification and compression prior to over-the-air transmission, where the model aggregation is reconstructed at ES via compressed sensing methods.

Besides, the distributive data among edge devices are typically neither independent nor identically distributed. This causes a major challenge called the statistical heterogeneity problem, which reduces the learning performance [12]. To address this problem, the authors in [13] proposed the federated multi-task learning (FMTL) framework to implement multiple machine learning tasks over the FL communication network, motivated by the multi-task learning frameworks [14, 15]. Empirical results demonstrate that FMTL can significantly improve the generalizability of the trained models in the presence of statistical heterogeneity, where the knowledge contained in one task can be leveraged in training the models of the other tasks. Different from the method in [13] only supporting a linear model or a linear combination of pre-trained models, the authors in [16, 17, 18] proposed other FMTL approaches to train more general non-convex learning models such as deep neural networks. To reduce the communication overhead, over-the-air computation is still an appealing solution to the uplink communication design of FMTL. Yet, the inter-task interference arises due to the concurrent transmissions of the model updates of multiple tasks. The inter-task interference, if not appropriately handled, will incur significant model aggregation errors that seriously degrade the learning performance.

To address the above challenge, in this paper, we propose the over-the-air FMTL (OA-FMTL) framework to achieve communication-efficient FMTL in the presence of inter-task interference, where multiple learning tasks are deployed on edge devices and a single ES. The ES is dedicated to parameter learning of multiple tasks, and the model aggregations of all the tasks are concurrently conducted at the ES via over-the-air computation. More specifically, at each edge device, the local model updates of all tasks are first sparsified and compressed individually by following the approach in [7, 5], and then superimposed and sent over the uplink channel. At the ES, the model aggregations of all the tasks are reconstructed from the channel observation data, based on a modified version of the turbo compressed sensing (Turbo-CS) algorithm [19] (named as M-Turbo-CS). It is clear that the above non-orthogonal transmission of multi-task model updates reduces the required uplink communication resource, but at the cost of severe inter-task interference. We show that our proposed OA-FMTL framework with M-Turbo-CS is able to efficiently suppress the inter-task interference, thereby significantly reducing the communication overhead, as compared to its counterpart with orthogonal multi-task transmission.

We further analyze the performance of the proposed OA-FMTL framework together with the M-Turbo-CS algorithm. Specially, we establish the state evolution to characterize the behaviour of the M-Turbo-CS algorithm. We then develop an upper bound on the learning loss of the OA-FMTL framework by taking model aggregation errors introduced by model sparsification, model misalignment, as well as imperfect reconstruction by M-Turbo-CS, into account. Based on that, we formulate a communication-learning optimization problem to improve the system performance by adjusting the power allocation among multiple tasks on the edge devices. We show that, under mild conditions, the problem can be solved by a feasibility test together with bisection search.

Numerical simulations show that our proposed OA-FMTL effectively suppresses the inter-task interference, so as to achieve a learning performance comparable to the single-task counterpart scheme [10, 11]. In other words, the communication overhead of OA-FMTL is only approximately one N𝑁N-th of the conventional orthogonal scheme with independent training of each task, where N𝑁N is the total number of tasks. Meanwhile, simulations also show that our proposed optimization algorithm further reduces the communication overhead by appropriately adjusting the power allocation among the tasks.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. In Section II, we describe the FMTL model and the over-the-air model aggregation framework. In Section III, we give the specific implementation of the OA-FMTL framework, including operations at devices, operations at the ES, and the design of the M-Turbo-CS algorithm. In Section IV, we analyze the performance of OA-FMTL and formulate an optimization problem that minimizes the training loss. In Section V, we develop an effective algorithm to solve the optimization problem. In Section VI, we validate our proposed OA-FMTL framework with experiments.

II-B Over-the-Air Channel Model

We now describe the wireless channels used to support the above FMTL process. It is well known that the communication bottleneck of FL resides in the uplink gradient aggregation. Thus, following the convention in [10, 11, 21], we assume error-free transmission in the downlink; and focus on the system design for the uplink. We model the wireless uplink as a block-fading multiple access (MAC) channel, where the channel state information (CSI) remains unchanged within s𝑠s channel uses. Since the update in (II-A) depends only on the sum of the local gradients, we employ the over-the-air computation for efficient model aggregation. Specifically, at the t𝑡t-th communication round, the devices, each equipped with a signal antenna, send their signal to the ES over the block-fading MAC channel with s𝑠s channel uses, characterized by

𝒓(t)=∑m=1Mhm(t)​𝒙m(t)+𝒘,superscript𝒓𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑚𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑚𝑡𝒘\bm{r}^{(t)}=\sum_{m=1}^{M}h_{m}^{(t)}\bm{x}_{m}^{(t)}+\bm{w}, (8)

where 𝒙m(t)∈ℂssuperscriptsubscript𝒙𝑚𝑡superscriptℂ𝑠\bm{x}_{m}^{(t)}\in\mathbb{C}^{s} is the channel input vector from device m𝑚m, hm(t)∈ℂsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑚𝑡ℂh_{m}^{(t)}\in\mathbb{C} is the channel gain from device m𝑚m to the ES, 𝒓(t)∈ℂssuperscript𝒓𝑡superscriptℂ𝑠\bm{r}^{(t)}\in\mathbb{C}^{s} is the channel output received by the ES, and 𝒘∈ℂs𝒘superscriptℂ𝑠\bm{w}\in\mathbb{C}^{s} is an independent additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) with each element independent and identically distributed as 𝒞​𝒩​(0,σw2)𝒞𝒩0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑤2\mathcal{CN}(0,\sigma_{w}^{2}). The power consumption of device m𝑚m at each round t𝑡t is constrained by

𝔼​[‖xm,k(t)‖2]≤Pm,𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑚𝑘𝑡2subscript𝑃𝑚\mathbb{E}[||x_{m,k}^{(t)}||^{2}]\leq P_{m}, (9)

where xm,k(t)superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑚𝑘𝑡x_{m,k}^{(t)} is the k𝑘k-th entry of 𝒙m(t)superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑚𝑡\bm{x}_{m}^{(t)}, and Pmsubscript𝑃𝑚P_{m} is the power budget of device m𝑚m.

The remaining issue is to map the gradient vectors {𝒈n​m(t)}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒈𝑛𝑚𝑡𝑛1𝑁\{\bm{g}_{nm}^{(t)}\}_{n=1}^{N} to the complex vector 𝒙m(t)superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑚𝑡\bm{x}_{m}^{(t)} at device m𝑚m in each communication round t𝑡t, and to recover ∇ℒ​(𝚯(t))∇ℒsuperscript𝚯𝑡\nabla\mathcal{L}(\bm{\Theta}^{(t)}) in (6) from 𝒓(t)superscript𝒓𝑡\bm{r}^{(t)} at the ES. As inspired by [11, 10, 21, 19, 22], we employ compressed sensing and error accumulation techniques to improve the communication efficiency. The details of the uplink transceiver design in the devices and the ES are presented in what follows.

III Proposed Transmission Scheme

III-A Operations at Devices

To support the uplink transmission of the OA-FMTL framework, we process the local gradients of each task n𝑛n on device m𝑚m, with the gradient sparsification scheme proposed in [11] and a distinct gradient compression scheme proposed in this paper. Then 𝒈n​msp⁡(t)superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑛𝑚sp𝑡\bm{g}_{nm}^{\operatorname{sp}(t)} is normalized to 𝒈n​mno⁡(t)∈ℝdsuperscriptsubscript𝒈𝑛𝑚no𝑡superscriptℝ𝑑\bm{g}_{nm}^{\operatorname{no}(t)}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} by

𝒈n​mno⁡(t)=𝒔n∘𝒈n​msp(t)vn​m(t),superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑛𝑚no𝑡subscript𝒔𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑛𝑚superscriptsp𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛𝑚𝑡\bm{g}_{nm}^{\operatorname{no}(t)}=\frac{\bm{s}_{n}\circ\bm{g}_{nm}^{\operatorname{sp}^{(t)}}}{v_{nm}^{(t)}}, (13)

where vn​m(t)=1d​‖𝒈n​msp⁡(t)‖superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛𝑚𝑡1𝑑normsuperscriptsubscript𝒈𝑛𝑚sp𝑡{v_{nm}^{(t)}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{d}}||\bm{g}_{nm}^{\operatorname{sp}(t)}|| is a normalization factor, and 𝒔n∈ℝdsubscript𝒔𝑛superscriptℝ𝑑\bm{s}_{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is a random sign vector with the entries independently and uniformly drawn from {+1,−1}11\{+1,-1\}. Note that 𝒔nsubscript𝒔𝑛\bm{s}_{n} ensures that the entries of 𝒈n​mno⁡(t)superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑛𝑚no𝑡\bm{g}_{nm}^{\operatorname{no}(t)} have zero-mean, and 𝒈n​mno⁡(t)superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑛𝑚no𝑡\bm{g}_{nm}^{\operatorname{no}(t)} of task n𝑛n is independent of the gradients of the other tasks.

Next 𝒈n​mno⁡(t)superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑛𝑚no𝑡\bm{g}_{nm}^{\operatorname{no}(t)} is compressed into a low-dimensional vector 𝒈n​mcp⁡(t)∈ℝ2​ssuperscriptsubscript𝒈𝑛𝑚cp𝑡superscriptℝ2𝑠\bm{g}_{nm}^{\operatorname{cp}(t)}\in\mathbb{R}^{2s} by a compression matrix 𝑨n∈ℝ2​s×dsubscript𝑨𝑛superscriptℝ2𝑠𝑑\bm{A}_{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{2s\times d} as

𝒈n​mcp⁡(t)=𝑨n​𝒈n​mno⁡(t),∀m∈[M],∀n∈[N],formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝒈𝑛𝑚cp𝑡subscript𝑨𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑛𝑚no𝑡formulae-sequencefor-all𝑚delimited-[]𝑀for-all𝑛delimited-[]𝑁\bm{g}_{nm}^{\operatorname{cp}(t)}=\bm{A}_{n}\bm{g}_{nm}^{\operatorname{no}(t)},\forall m\in[M],\forall n\in[N], (14)

where each task n𝑛n is assigned with an individual compression matrix 𝑨nsubscript𝑨𝑛\bm{A}_{n}. Unlike the classic over-the-air FL framework [11, 10], our proposed OA-FMTL framework needs to enable the concurrent reconstruction of the gradient aggregations of the N𝑁N tasks at the ES, where the randomness of the compression matrices is introduced to help eliminate the inter-task interference. In specific, we employ a partial discrete cosine transform (DCT) matrix 𝑨n=𝑺n​𝑭subscript𝑨𝑛subscript𝑺𝑛𝑭\bm{A}_{n}=\bm{S}_{n}\bm{F} for each task n𝑛n, where the selection matrix 𝑺n∈ℝ2​s×dsubscript𝑺𝑛superscriptℝ2𝑠𝑑\bm{S}_{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{2s\times d} consists of 2​s2𝑠2s randomly selected rows of the d×d𝑑𝑑d\times d identity matrix 𝑰dsubscript𝑰𝑑\bm{I}_{d} and the (m,n)𝑚𝑛(m,n)-th entry of the unitary DCT matrix 𝑭∈ℝd×d𝑭superscriptℝ𝑑𝑑\bm{F}\in\mathbb{R}^{{d}\times{d}} is given by 2d​cos⁡((m−1)​(2​n−1)​π2​d)2𝑑cos𝑚12𝑛1𝜋2𝑑\sqrt{\frac{2}{d}}\operatorname{cos}\left(\frac{(m-1)(2n-1)\pi}{2d}\right) when m≠1𝑚1m\neq 1, or 1d1𝑑\sqrt{\frac{1}{d}} when m=1𝑚1m=1. Compared to other choices of the compression matrix such as the i.i.d. Gaussian matrix, the partial DCT matrix has advantages both in performance and complexity [23].

We are now ready to describe the design of 𝒙m(t)superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑚𝑡\bm{x}_{m}^{(t)}. As a distinct feature of the OA-FMTL framework, we propose to superimpose the local gradients of different tasks to support the multiplexing of the N𝑁N learning tasks. In specific, each device m𝑚m constructs

𝒙ˇm(t)=∑n=1Nγn(t)​𝒈n​mcp⁡(t)∈ℝ2​s,superscriptsubscriptˇ𝒙𝑚𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑛𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑛𝑚cp𝑡superscriptℝ2𝑠\check{\bm{x}}_{m}^{(t)}=\sum_{n=1}^{N}\sqrt{\gamma_{n}^{(t)}}\bm{g}_{nm}^{\operatorname{cp}(t)}\in\mathbb{R}^{2s}, (15)

where γn(t)∈ℝ+superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑛𝑡superscriptℝ\gamma_{n}^{(t)}\in\mathbb{R}^{+} is the inter-task power allocation coefficient of task n𝑛n. Im⁡{𝒙~m(t)}Imsuperscriptsubscript~𝒙𝑚𝑡\displaystyle\operatorname{Im}\{\tilde{\bm{x}}_{m}^{(t)}\} =[xˇm,s+1(t),…,xˇm,2​s(t)]T,absentsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptˇ𝑥𝑚𝑠1𝑡…superscriptsubscriptˇ𝑥𝑚2𝑠𝑡𝑇\displaystyle=\left[\check{x}_{m,s+1}^{(t)},\dots,\check{x}_{m,2s}^{(t)}\right]^{T}, (16b)

After that, every device m𝑚m concurrently sends 𝒙m(t)=αm(t)​𝒙~m(t)superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑚𝑡superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑚𝑡superscriptsubscript~𝒙𝑚𝑡\bm{x}_{m}^{(t)}=\alpha_{m}^{(t)}\tilde{\bm{x}}_{m}^{(t)} to the ES via analog transmission, where the power allocation cofficient αm(t)∈ℂsuperscriptsubscript𝛼𝑚𝑡ℂ\alpha_{m}^{(t)}\in\mathbb{C} is given by

αm(t)=|hm(t)|hm(t)​Pm2.superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑚𝑡superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑚𝑡superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑚𝑡subscript𝑃𝑚2\alpha_{m}^{(t)}=\frac{|h_{m}^{(t)}|}{h_{m}^{(t)}}\sqrt{\frac{P_{m}}{2}}. (17)

We see that the phase of αm(t)superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑚𝑡\alpha_{m}^{(t)} is opposite to the phase of hm(t)superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑚𝑡h_{m}^{(t)}, and that with αm(t)superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑚𝑡\alpha_{m}^{(t)} in (17), the transmission power of every device meets the power budget. This avoids the hard alignment of local gradients and hence improves the system performance; see, e.g., [24] for more detailed discussions.

where η𝜂\eta is defined below (6).

III-C Modified Turbo Compressed Sensing (M-Turbo-CS)

The recovery of {𝒈n(t)}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒈𝑛𝑡𝑛1𝑁\{\bm{g}_{n}^{(t)}\}_{n=1}^{N} from 𝒚(t)superscript𝒚𝑡\bm{y}^{(t)} in (18) is a compressed sensing problem, where the compression matrix 𝑨=[𝑨1,…,𝑨N]∈ℝ2​s×d​N𝑨subscript𝑨1…subscript𝑨𝑁superscriptℝ2𝑠𝑑𝑁\bm{A}=[\bm{A}_{1},\dots,\bm{A}_{N}]\in\mathbb{R}^{2s\times dN} composed of N𝑁N partial DCT matrices is partial orthogonal, i.e., 𝑨​𝑨T=𝑰2​s𝑨superscript𝑨𝑇subscript𝑰2𝑠\bm{A}\bm{A}^{T}=\bm{I}_{2s}. It is known that the Turbo-CS algorithm [19] is the state-of-the-art compressed sensing problem to handle partial-orthogonal sensing matrices. Inspired by this, we basically follow the idea of Turbo-CS to solve the compressed sensing problem involved in (18). But the difference is that, as each 𝒈n(t)superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑛𝑡\bm{g}_{n}^{(t)} is the gradient for a different task n𝑛n, {𝒈n(t)}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒈𝑛𝑡𝑛1𝑁\{\bm{g}_{n}^{(t)}\}_{n=1}^{N} generally have different prior distributions. With (13)-(18), we assume that the entries of 𝒈n(t)superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑛𝑡\bm{g}_{n}^{(t)} are independently drawn from a Bernoulli Gaussian distribution:

gn,k(t)∼{0, probability =1−λn(t),𝒩​(0,γn(t)), probability =λn(t),similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑛𝑘𝑡cases0 probability 1superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑛𝑡𝒩0superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑛𝑡 probability superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑛𝑡g_{n,k}^{(t)}\sim\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}0,&\text{ probability }=1-\lambda_{n}^{(t)},\\ \mathcal{N}\left(0,\gamma_{n}^{(t)}\right),&\text{ probability }=\lambda_{n}^{(t)},\end{array}\right. (21)

where gn,k(t)superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑛𝑘𝑡g_{n,k}^{(t)} is the k𝑘k-th element of 𝒈n(t)superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑛𝑡\bm{g}_{n}^{(t)}, λn(t)superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑛𝑡\lambda_{n}^{(t)} is the sparsity of 𝒈n(t)superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑛𝑡\bm{g}_{n}^{(t)}, and γn(t)superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑛𝑡\gamma_{n}^{(t)} is the inter-task power allocation coefficient defined in (15). The sparsity λn(t)superscriptsubscript𝜆𝑛𝑡\lambda_{n}^{(t)} in the prior distribution is estimated by the expectation-maximization algorithm [25]. With the above prior model, we modify the Turbo-CS algorithm accordingly to accommodate concurrent model aggregations of the N𝑁N tasks as follows.

As shown in Fig. 2, M-Turbo-CS iterates between two modules where module A is a linear minimum mean-squared error (LMMSE) [26] estimator handling the linear constraint in (18), and module B is a minimum mean-squared error (MMSE) [26] denoiser exploiting the gradient sparsity in (21). The two modules are executed iteratively until convergence. For brevity, we henceforth drop out the round index t𝑡t in circumstances without causing ambiguity. The detailed operations of the iterative algorithm are provided below.

The iterative process begins with Module A. At the end of the iterative process, the final estimate of 𝒈nsubscript𝒈𝑛\bm{g}_{n} is based on the a posterior output of the MMSE denoiser, i.e., 𝒈^n=𝒈B,np​o​s​tsubscript^𝒈𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒈𝐵𝑛𝑝𝑜𝑠𝑡\hat{\bm{g}}_{n}=\bm{g}_{B,n}^{post}.

To sum up, at each round t𝑡t, given the initialization values 𝒈A,np​r​i=𝟎superscriptsubscript𝒈𝐴𝑛𝑝𝑟𝑖0\bm{g}_{A,n}^{pri}=\bm{0} and vA,np​r​i=1superscriptsubscript𝑣𝐴𝑛𝑝𝑟𝑖1v_{A,n}^{pri}=1 defined in (21) for ∀n∈[N]for-all𝑛delimited-[]𝑁\forall n\in[N], (22)-(24) and (26)-(28) are iterated until a certain termination criterion is met, and 𝒈B,np​o​s​tsuperscriptsubscript𝒈𝐵𝑛𝑝𝑜𝑠𝑡\bm{g}_{B,n}^{post} is output as 𝒈^n(t)superscriptsubscript^𝒈𝑛𝑡\hat{\bm{g}}_{n}^{(t)} to compute 𝒈ˇn(t)superscriptsubscriptˇ𝒈𝑛𝑡\check{\bm{g}}_{n}^{(t)} for the model update in (20), for ∀n∈[N]for-all𝑛delimited-[]𝑁\forall n\in[N]. Compared with the original Turbo-CS algorithm in [19], the main difference is that each subvector 𝒈nsubscript𝒈𝑛\bm{g}_{n} in (18) has its individual prior distribution as in (21). Later, we will show by performance analysis and numerical experiments in Section IV-A that the M-Turbo-CS algorithm is able to efficiently suppress the inter-task interference in model aggregation.

III-D Overall Scheme

The overall scheme is summarized in Algorithm 1, where Lines 3-7 are executed at the devices, and Lines 8-19 are executed at the ES. Particularly, Line 15 of Algorithm 1 involves the optimization of this scheme, which will be elaborated later in Section V. In what follows, we present the performance analysis of the proposed scheme.

IV Performance Analysis

IV-A Performance Analysis of M-Turbo-CS

To start with, we first describe the performance analysis of the M-Turbo-CS algorithm via state evolution. The main idea of state evolution is to characterize the behavior of the Turbo-CS algorithm by the variance transfer functions of the two modules [23]. Specifically, the variance transfer functions of Module A are defined by

Besides, from the performance analysis of M-Turbo-CS in Section IV-A, M-Turbo-CS converges to the fixed point {vn⋆(t)}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛⋆𝑡𝑛1𝑁\{{v_{n}^{\star}}^{(t)}\}_{n=1}^{N} at the t𝑡t-th round, for ∀n∈[N]for-all𝑛delimited-[]𝑁\forall n\in[N]. Thus, we have

𝔼​[‖𝒆n,3(t)‖2]=∑m=1M|hm(t)​αm(t)|2​ζn(t)2​γn(t)​vn⋆(t).𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝒆𝑛3𝑡2superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑚𝑡superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑚𝑡2superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜁𝑛𝑡2superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑛𝑡superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛⋆𝑡\mathbb{E}[||\bm{e}_{n,3}^{(t)}||^{2}]=\sum_{m=1}^{M}|h_{m}^{(t)}\alpha_{m}^{(t)}|^{2}{\zeta_{n}^{(t)}}^{2}\gamma_{n}^{(t)}{v_{n}^{\star}}^{(t)}. (37)

IV-C Convergence Analysis

To proceed, we make assumptions by following the convention in stochastic optimization [27].

Assumption 1.

ℒn​(⋅)subscriptℒ𝑛⋅\mathcal{L}_{n}(\cdot) is strongly convex with some (positive) parameter ΩnsubscriptΩ𝑛\Omega_{n}. That is, ℒn​(𝐲)≥ℒn​(𝐱)+(𝐲−𝐱)T​∇nℒn​(𝐱)+Ωn2​‖𝐲−𝐱‖2,∀𝐱,𝐲∈ℝd,∀n∈[N]formulae-sequencesubscriptℒ𝑛𝐲subscriptℒ𝑛𝐱superscript𝐲𝐱𝑇subscript∇𝑛subscriptℒ𝑛𝐱subscriptΩ𝑛2superscriptnorm𝐲𝐱2for-all𝐱formulae-sequence𝐲superscriptℝ𝑑for-all𝑛delimited-[]𝑁\mathcal{L}_{n}(\bm{y})\geq\mathcal{L}_{n}(\bm{x})+(\bm{y}-\bm{x})^{T}\nabla_{n}\mathcal{L}_{n}(\bm{x})+\frac{\Omega_{n}}{2}\|\bm{y}-\bm{x}\|^{2},\forall\bm{x},\bm{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{d},\forall n\in[N].

Assumption 2.

The gradient ∇nℒn​(⋅)subscript∇𝑛subscriptℒ𝑛⋅\nabla_{n}\mathcal{L}_{n}(\cdot) is Lipschitz continuous with some (positive) parameter L𝐿L. That is, ‖∇nℒn​(𝐱)−∇nℒn​(𝐲)‖≤Ln​‖𝐱−𝐲‖,∀𝐱,𝐲∈ℝd,∀n∈[N]formulae-sequencenormsubscript∇𝑛subscriptℒ𝑛𝐱subscript∇𝑛subscriptℒ𝑛𝐲subscript𝐿𝑛norm𝐱𝐲for-all𝐱formulae-sequence𝐲superscriptℝ𝑑for-all𝑛delimited-[]𝑁\|\nabla_{n}\mathcal{L}_{n}(\bm{x})-\nabla_{n}\mathcal{L}_{n}(\bm{y})\|\leq L_{n}\|\bm{x}-\bm{y}\|,\forall\bm{x},\bm{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{d},\forall n\in[N].

Assumption 3.

ℒn​(⋅)subscriptℒ𝑛⋅\mathcal{L}_{n}(\cdot) is twice-continuously differentiable, for ∀n∈[N]for-all𝑛delimited-[]𝑁\forall n\in[N].

Assumption 4.

The gradient with respect to any training sample, denoted by ∇nln​(𝛉n;⋅)subscript∇𝑛subscript𝑙𝑛subscript𝛉𝑛⋅\nabla_{n}l_{n}(\bm{\theta}_{n};\cdot), is upper bounded at 𝛉nsubscript𝛉𝑛\bm{\theta}_{n} as

‖∇nln​(𝜽n,𝒖n​m​k)‖2≤βn,1+βn,2​‖∇nℒn​(𝜽n)‖2,∀n∈[N]formulae-sequencesuperscriptnormsubscript∇𝑛subscript𝑙𝑛subscript𝜽𝑛subscript𝒖𝑛𝑚𝑘2subscript𝛽𝑛1subscript𝛽𝑛2superscriptnormsubscript∇𝑛subscriptℒ𝑛subscript𝜽𝑛2for-all𝑛delimited-[]𝑁\left\|\nabla_{n}l_{n}(\bm{\theta}_{n},\bm{u}_{nmk})\right\|^{2}\leq\beta_{n,1}+\beta_{n,2}\left\|\nabla_{n}\mathcal{L}_{n}\left(\bm{\theta}_{n}\right)\right\|^{2},\forall n\in[N]

for some constants βn,1≥0subscript𝛽𝑛10\beta_{n,1}\geq 0 and βn,2>0subscript𝛽𝑛20\beta_{n,2}>0.

Assumptions 1-4 lead to an upper bound on the loss function ℒn​(𝜽n(t+1))subscriptℒ𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜽𝑛𝑡1\mathcal{L}_{n}(\bm{\theta}_{n}^{(t+1)}) with respect to the model updating (20), as given in the following lemma.

See [27, Lemma 2.1]. ∎

We are now ready to derive an upper bound of the expected difference between the training loss and the optimal loss at round t+1𝑡1t+1, i.e., 𝔼​[ℒ​(𝚯(t+1))−ℒ​(𝚯(t))]𝔼delimited-[]ℒsuperscript𝚯𝑡1ℒsuperscript𝚯𝑡\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\bm{\Theta}^{(t+1)})-\mathcal{L}(\bm{\Theta}^{(t)})].

From Theorem 1, we see that 𝔼​[ℒ​(𝚯(t))−ℒ​(𝚯(⋆))]𝔼delimited-[]ℒsuperscript𝚯𝑡ℒsuperscript𝚯⋆\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\bm{\Theta}^{(t)})-\mathcal{L}(\bm{\Theta}^{(\star)})], the expected difference between the training loss and the optimal loss at the t𝑡t-th round, is upper bounded by the right-hand side of the inequality in (1). Moreover, this upper bound converges with speed maxn⁡Υnsubscript𝑛subscriptΥ𝑛\max_{n}\Upsilon_{n} when maxn⁡Υn<1subscript𝑛subscriptΥ𝑛1\max_{n}\Upsilon_{n}<1. Empirically, we find that the proposed OA-FMTL scheme always converges with appropriately chosen system parameters. The following corollary further characterizes the convergence behavior of 𝔼​[ℒ​(𝚯(t+1))−ℒ​(𝚯(⋆))]𝔼delimited-[]ℒsuperscript𝚯𝑡1ℒsuperscript𝚯⋆\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\bm{\Theta}^{(t+1)})-\mathcal{L}(\bm{\Theta}^{(\star)})].

Corollary 1.

Suppose that Assumptions 1-4 hold, and that maxn⁡Υn<1subscript𝑛subscriptΥ𝑛1\max_{n}\Upsilon_{n}<1 for ∀nfor-all𝑛\forall n. Then, as t→∞→𝑡t\rightarrow\infty, we have

limt→∞𝔼​[ℒ​(𝚯(t+1))−ℒ​(𝚯(⋆))]≤∑t′=1t∑n=1NCn(t′)subscript→𝑡𝔼delimited-[]ℒsuperscript𝚯𝑡1ℒsuperscript𝚯⋆superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑡′1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑛superscript𝑡′\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\bm{\Theta}^{(t+1)})-\mathcal{L}(\bm{\Theta}^{(\star)})]\leq\sum_{t^{\prime}=1}^{t}\sum_{n=1}^{N}C_{n}^{(t^{\prime})} (42)
Proof.

When maxn⁡Υn<1subscript𝑛subscriptΥ𝑛1\max_{n}\Upsilon_{n}<1, we have limt→∞(maxn⁡Υn)t=0subscript→𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑛subscriptΥ𝑛𝑡0\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}(\max_{n}\Upsilon_{n})^{t}=0. Plugging this result and the assumption into (1), we obtain (42). ∎

Corollary 1 shows that OA-FMTL guarantees to converge with a sufficiently small maxn⁡Υnsubscript𝑛subscriptΥ𝑛\max_{n}\Upsilon_{n}. However, there generally exists a gap between the converged loss limt→∞𝔼​[ℒ​(𝚯(t+1))]subscript→𝑡𝔼delimited-[]ℒsuperscript𝚯𝑡1\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\bm{\Theta}^{(t+1)})] and the optimal one 𝔼​[ℒ​(𝚯(⋆))]𝔼delimited-[]ℒsuperscript𝚯⋆\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\bm{\Theta}^{(\star)})] because of the communication noise and the inter-task interference. Therefore, we next aim to minimize the gap, so as to optimize our proposed framework.

V Optimization

V-A Problem Formulation

From Theorem 1 and Corollary 1, we see that the term ∑t′=1t∑n=1NCn(t′)superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑡′1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑛superscript𝑡′\sum_{t^{\prime}=1}^{t}\sum_{n=1}^{N}C_{n}^{(t^{\prime})} in (42) represents the impact of the misalignment error and the estimation error caused by M-Turbo-CS on the convergence rate and the asymptotic learning performance. Specifically, a smaller ∑t′=1t∑n=1NCn(t)superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑡′1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑛𝑡\sum_{t^{\prime}=1}^{t}\sum_{n=1}^{N}C_{n}^{(t)} leads to faster convergence and a smaller gap in limt→∞𝔼​[ℒ​(𝚯(t+1))−ℒ​(𝚯(⋆))]subscript→𝑡𝔼delimited-[]ℒsuperscript𝚯𝑡1ℒsuperscript𝚯⋆\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}\mathbb{E}[\mathcal{L}(\bm{\Theta}^{(t+1)})-\mathcal{L}(\bm{\Theta}^{(\star)})]. This motivates us to use ∑t′=1t∑n=1NCn(t′)superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑡′1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑛superscript𝑡′\sum_{t^{\prime}=1}^{t}\sum_{n=1}^{N}C_{n}^{(t^{\prime})} as the metric of the FL performance, i.e., to minimize ∑n=1NCn(t)superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐶𝑛𝑡\sum_{n=1}^{N}C_{n}^{(t)} over {{γn(t)}n=1N,{ζn(t)}n=1N}superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝛾𝑛𝑡𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜁𝑛𝑡𝑛1𝑁\{\{\gamma_{n}^{(t)}\}_{n=1}^{N},\{\zeta_{n}^{(t)}\}_{n=1}^{N}\} at each round t𝑡t. We drop out the round index t𝑡t in the following for brevity, and formulate the design problem as

where each vn⋆superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛⋆v_{n}^{\star}, which is in general a function of {γn}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝛾𝑛𝑛1𝑁\{\gamma_{n}\}_{n=1}^{N}, is the fixed point of the state evolution in (29) and (31). In problem 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1}, the objective function (43a) is equivalent to ∑n=1NCnsuperscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝐶𝑛\sum_{n=1}^{N}C_{n} in (40) by dropping the term irrelevant to {{γn}n=1N,{ζn}n=1N}superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝛾𝑛𝑛1𝑁superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜁𝑛𝑛1𝑁\{\{\gamma_{n}\}_{n=1}^{N},\{\zeta_{n}\}_{n=1}^{N}\}; the constraint (43c) is obtained by substituting (13)-(17) into the power constraint (9).

By inspection, it is not difficult to see that 𝒫2subscript𝒫2\mathcal{P}_{2} has the same solution as 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1}. However, the fixed point {vn⋆}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛⋆𝑛1𝑁\{v_{n}^{\star}\}_{n=1}^{N} in the constraint (44d) still does not have a closed-form expression. V-B Algorithm Design

In this subsection, we first give an equivalent form of Problem 𝒫3subscript𝒫3\mathcal{P}_{3}. We then show that the equivalent problem 𝒫4subscript𝒫4\mathcal{P}_{4} is readily solved by using existing optimization tools. The details are provided in the following propositions.

Proposition 3.

For fixed {vntarget}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛target𝑛1𝑁\{v_{n}^{\mathrm{target}}\}_{n=1}^{N}, Problem 𝒫4subscript𝒫4\mathcal{P}_{4} for finding {γn}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝛾𝑛𝑛1𝑁\{\gamma_{n}\}_{n=1}^{N} reduces to a convex feasibility test problem as

Proposition 4.

Suppose that for given {vntarget=v~n}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛targetsubscript~𝑣𝑛𝑛1𝑁\{v_{n}^{\mathrm{target}}=\tilde{v}_{n}\}_{n=1}^{N}, Problem 𝒫5subscript𝒫5\mathcal{P}_{5} is feasible. Then for any {vntarget}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛target𝑛1𝑁\{v_{n}^{\mathrm{target}}\}_{n=1}^{N} satisfying vntarget≥v~nsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛targetsubscript~𝑣𝑛v_{n}^{\text{target}}\geq\tilde{v}_{n}, for n=1,…,N𝑛1…𝑁n=1,\dots,N, Problem 𝒫5subscript𝒫5\mathcal{P}_{5} is feasible. On the contrary, suppose that for given {vntarget=v~n}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛targetsubscript~𝑣𝑛𝑛1𝑁\{v_{n}^{\mathrm{target}}=\tilde{v}_{n}\}_{n=1}^{N}, Problem 𝒫5subscript𝒫5\mathcal{P}_{5} is infeasible. Then for any {vntarget}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛target𝑛1𝑁\{v_{n}^{\mathrm{target}}\}_{n=1}^{N} satisfying vntarget≤v~nsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛targetsubscript~𝑣𝑛v_{n}^{\mathrm{target}}\leq\tilde{v}_{n}, for n=1,…,N𝑛1…𝑁n=1,\dots,N, Problem 𝒫5subscript𝒫5\mathcal{P}_{5} is infeasible.

Proof.

We define the feasible region of Problem 𝒫5subscript𝒫5\mathcal{P}_{5} as 𝒮​(v1target,…,vNtarget)𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑣1target…superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑁target\mathcal{S}(v_{1}^{\text{target}},\dots,v_{N}^{\text{target}}). Based on constraints (53d), we see that for any {vntarget}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛target𝑛1𝑁\{v_{n}^{\mathrm{target}}\}_{n=1}^{N} satisfying vntarget≥v~nsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛targetsubscript~𝑣𝑛v_{n}^{\text{target}}\geq\tilde{v}_{n}, 𝒮​(v1target,…,vNtarget)⊆𝒮​(v~1,…,v~N)𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑣1target…superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑁target𝒮subscript~𝑣1…subscript~𝑣𝑁\mathcal{S}(v_{1}^{\text{target}},\dots,v_{N}^{\text{target}})\subseteq\mathcal{S}(\tilde{v}_{1},\dots,\tilde{v}_{N}) holds. Similarly, for any {vntarget}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛target𝑛1𝑁\{v_{n}^{\mathrm{target}}\}_{n=1}^{N} satisfying vntarget≤v~nsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛targetsubscript~𝑣𝑛v_{n}^{\text{target}}\leq\tilde{v}_{n}, we obtain 𝒮​(v1target,…,vNtarget)⊇𝒮​(v~1,…,v~N)𝒮subscript~𝑣1…subscript~𝑣𝑁𝒮superscriptsubscript𝑣1target…superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑁target\mathcal{S}(v_{1}^{\text{target}},\dots,v_{N}^{\text{target}})\supseteq\mathcal{S}(\tilde{v}_{1},\dots,\tilde{v}_{N}). Therefore, Proposition 4 holds. ∎

From Propositions 1-3, to solve Problem 𝒫3subscript𝒫3\mathcal{P}_{3}, it suffices to find the minimum values of {vntarget}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛target𝑛1𝑁\{v_{n}^{\text{target}}\}_{n=1}^{N} such that Problem 𝒫5subscript𝒫5\mathcal{P}_{5} is feasible. From Proposition 4, the minimum values of {vntarget}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛target𝑛1𝑁\{v_{n}^{\text{target}}\}_{n=1}^{N} can be found by applying bisection search to each vntargetsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛targetv_{n}^{\text{target}}. In addition, it is difficult to handle the constraint (53d) of each vnsubscript𝑣𝑛v_{n} over the entire continuous region [vntarget,1)superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛target1[v_{n}^{\text{target}},1). In practice, we require that (53d) holds only on some discrete points of vnsubscript𝑣𝑛v_{n} within [vntarget,1)superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛target1[v_{n}^{\text{target}},1). Then, the feasibility test 𝒫5subscript𝒫5\mathcal{P}_{5} can be solved by using standard convex optimization tools. The optimization algorithm is summarized in Algorithm 2.

VI Numerical Results

VI-A Experimental Settings

We validate our proposed OA-FMTL framework with experiments, and provide some baseline schemes for comparison:

  • •

    Error-free bound: This bound assumes that the ES receives all the local gradients in an error-free fashion and updates the global model by (6) and (7).

  • •

    OA-FL with TDM and Turbo-CS: Time division multiplexing (TDM) is applied to the tasks, i.e., each task is assigned with an orthogonal time slot to avoid inter-task interference. OA-FL [10] is applied in transmission, and Turbo-CS [19] is applied to recover the model aggregation at the ES.

  • •

    OA-FMTL with Turbo-CS: The proposed OA-FMTL framework is applied to transmit the model parameters of all the tasks concurrently, and the Turbo-CS algorithm is used to individually recover the model aggregation of each task by treating the inter-task interference as noise.

  • •

    OA-FMTL with M-Turbo-CS: The proposed OA-FMTL framework is applied to transmit the model parameters of all the tasks concurrently, and the M-Turbo-CS algorithm is used to recover the model aggregations of all the tasks, as outlined in Algorithm 1.

To compare the performances of the above schemes, we design two classification experiments using two commonly used databases, namely, MNIST and Human Activity Recognition (HAR). The experimental settings are as follows.

  • •

    MNIST experiment: We consider federated image classification tasks on the MNIST dataset of handwritten digits [28] and the Fashion-MNIST dataset of fashion clothing [29] (i.e., N=2𝑁2N=2). For each task, we train a convolutional neural network with two 5×5555\times 5 convolution layers (the first with 10 channels, the second with 20, each followed with 2×2222\times 2 max pooling), a fully connected layer with 50 units and ReLu activation, and a final softmax output layer (model parameter length d=10920𝑑10920d=10920). The learning rate is set to η=0.1𝜂0.1\eta=0.1, and the compression ratio is set to 2​s/d=3/42𝑠𝑑342s/d=3/4.

  • •

    HAR experiment: The set of data gathered from accelerometers and gyroscopes of cell phones from 30 individuals performing six different activities including lying-down, standing, walking, sitting, walking-upstairs, and walking-downstairs [30]. We first divide 30 individuals into two groups (22 cases for model training and the other 8 for model testing); and then divide the training set into four subgroups with each subgroup assigned to an individual task classifying different human activities (i.e., N=4𝑁4N=4). For each task, we train a neural network consisting of one hidden layer with the output size of 100, and the ReLU activation function, and a softmax layer for network output (model parameter length d=56806𝑑56806d=56806). The learning rate is set to η=0.03𝜂0.03\eta=0.03, and the compression ratio is set to 2​s/d=4/52𝑠𝑑452s/d=4/5.

Other experimental settings are as follows: We consider a system of M=20𝑀20M=20 local devices; the channel gain hm(t)superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑚𝑡h_{m}^{(t)} follows the Rayleigh distribution with unit variance for ∀m∈[M]for-all𝑚delimited-[]𝑀\forall m\in[M].

VI-B Performance Comparisons

Fig. 4 compares the MSEs of the gradient aggregations of various schemes at t=90𝑡90t=90 round in the MNIST experiment. We see that the simulation results agree well with their corresponding state evolutions. We also see that OA-FMTL with M-Turbo-CS performs better in suppressing the inter-task interference than OA-FMTL with Turbo-CS. This is expected since the latter treats the inter-task interference as noise. Besides, due to no inter-task interference in TDM, the OA-FL with TDM and Turbo-CS outperforms the others in terms of MSE. However, we will show that the learning performance of OA-FMTL with M-Turbo-CS is comparable to that of OA-FL with TDM and Turbo-CS, which reveals that OA-FMTL has a strong error-tolerance capability in gradient aggregation. Fig. 5 shows the performances of the tasks in terms of test accuracy versus communication round t𝑡t. We observe that the test accuracy of OA-FMTL with M-Turbo-CS is close to that of OA-FL with TDM and Turbo-CS, and is better than that of OA-FMTL with Turbo-CS. We also note that the test accuracy of OA-FMTL with M-Turbo-CS is only about 2%-5% lower than that of the ideal error-free bound, which demonstrates the excellent interference suppression capability of OA-FMTL with M-Turbo-CS.

For further comparison, we define ξnmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝑛max\xi_{n}^{\text{max}} as the maximum test accuracy of each task n𝑛n, and define t⋆​(ξ)superscript𝑡⋆𝜉t^{\star}(\xi) as the total required rounds of communications for every task n𝑛n to reach its target accuracy ξ​ξnmax𝜉superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑛max\xi\xi_{n}^{\text{max}}, where ξ𝜉\xi is called the relative target accuracy. Thus, t⋆​(ξ)superscript𝑡⋆𝜉t^{\star}(\xi) of the scheme including the OA-FMTL framework is given by

t⋆​(ξ)=m​a​x​{t1⋆​(ξ),…,tN⋆​(ξ)},superscript𝑡⋆𝜉𝑚𝑎𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑡1⋆𝜉…superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑁⋆𝜉t^{\star}(\xi)=max\{t_{1}^{\star}(\xi),\dots,t_{N}^{\star}(\xi)\}, (54)

where tn⋆​(ξ)superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑛⋆𝜉t_{n}^{\star}(\xi) is the required communication rounds of task n𝑛n to reach its target accuracy ξ​ξnmax𝜉superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑛max\xi\xi_{n}^{\text{max}}. Besides, t⋆​(ξ)superscript𝑡⋆𝜉t^{\star}(\xi) of the scheme with TDM is given by

t⋆​(ξ)=∑n=0Ntn⋆​(ξ).superscript𝑡⋆𝜉superscriptsubscript𝑛0𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑛⋆𝜉t^{\star}(\xi)=\sum_{n=0}^{N}t_{n}^{\star}(\xi). (55)

Fig. 6 depicts the total required communication rounds t⋆superscript𝑡⋆t^{\star} versus relative target accuracy ξ𝜉\xi on the two experiments. We see that OA-FMTL with M-Turbo-CS significantly outperforms the other two baseline schemes, and that the total required communication rounds of OA-FMTL with M-Turbo-CS to complete N𝑁N tasks is only 1/N1𝑁1/N of that of OA-FL with TDM and Turbo-CS at any value of ξ𝜉\xi. In addition, we note that OA-FMTL with Turbo-CS also requires fewer communication rounds than OA-FL with TDM and Turbo-CS, which demonstrates the advantage of non-orthogonal transmission.

We next validate the performance of the power allocation optimization for OA-FMTL with M-Turbo-CS. We describe some inter-task power allocation approaches for comparison:

  • •

    Equal power allocation: This approach assume that an equal power is allocated to each task at each communication round, i.e., we set γ1=⋯=γNsubscript𝛾1⋯subscript𝛾𝑁\gamma_{1}=\dots=\gamma_{N} in Problem 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1}.

  • •

    Random power allocation: This approach randomly generates the inter-task power allocation coefficients {γn}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝛾𝑛𝑛1𝑁\{\gamma_{n}\}_{n=1}^{N} satisfying ∑n=1Nγn=1superscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁subscript𝛾𝑛1\sum_{n=1}^{N}\gamma_{n}=1.

  • •

    Optimized power allocation: This approach solves the optimization problem 𝒫3subscript𝒫3\mathcal{P}_{3} to obtain the inter-task power allocation coefficients {γn(t)}n=1Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝛾𝑛𝑡𝑛1𝑁\{\gamma_{n}^{(t)}\}_{n=1}^{N} at each communication round t𝑡t.

Fig. 7 shows the performance comparison of the three power allocation approaches on the MNIST experiment and the HAR experiment, where these ascending curves measure the performance of all the tasks in terms of test accuracy versus communication round t𝑡t; and these descending curves measure the total MSE, i.e., ∑n=1N‖𝒆n‖2/dsuperscriptsubscript𝑛1𝑁superscriptnormsubscript𝒆𝑛2𝑑\sum_{n=1}^{N}||\bm{e}_{n}||^{2}/d defined in (34), versus communication round t𝑡t. Similarly, Fig. 8 shows the performance comparison of the three power allocation approaches on the HAR experiment. We see that the accuracies of some tasks are improved, e.g., MNIST, HAR TASK 2 and HAR TASK 3 at the cost of a slight decrease in the accuracies of the other tasks. We also see that optimized power allocation reduces the total MSE as compared with the other approaches. Fig. 9 depicts the total required communication rounds t⋆superscript𝑡⋆t^{\star} of the three power allocation approaches on the two experiments, versus relative target accuracy ξ𝜉\xi. We see that random power allocation significantly increases the required number of communication rounds, compared to the other allocation approaches. We also see that our proposed optimized power allocation approach reduces the required communication rounds by 252525 at relative target accuracy ξ=1𝜉1\xi=1, compared to the equal power allocation approach. This illustrates again that the optimized power allocation approach improves the overall system performance.

VII Conclusions

We proposed the over-the-air FMTL (OA-FMTL) framework to achieve communication-efficient FMTL in the presence of inter-task interference. Specifically, we modified the original Turbo-CS algorithm in the compressed sensing context to reconstruct the sparsified model aggregation updates at ES. We further analyzed the performance of the proposed OA-FMTL framework together with the M-Turbo-CS algorithm. Based on that, we formulated a communication-learning optimization problem to improve the system performance by adjusting the power allocation between multiple tasks on the edge devices. We showed that, under mild conditions, the problem can be solved by a feasibility test together with bisection search. Numerical simulations showed that our proposed OA-FMTL can efficiently suppress the inter-task interference, so as to achieve a learning performance comparable to its counterpart with orthogonal multi-task transmission. Meanwhile, simulations also showed that our proposed optimization algorithm further reduces the communication overhead by appropriately adjusting the power allocation among the tasks.
